info.title: Enterprise Social Network Adoption in 5 Steps, 3rd Edition

chapter.title: State of the Nation
chapter.para: The world of social collaboration at work has morphed and expanded again since the second edition of this book was published in August 2015. In that there there is a renewed focus on discussion applications like IBM Watson Workspace, Cisco Spark, Slack and Microsoft Teams.

I can't readily prove this, but I am guessing the initial paradigm in social collaboration was that people liked to post status updates to applications like Facebook and LinkedIn, and so therefore basing social collaboration on "working out loud" was the most obvious way to implement a new model for business collaboration. It has, however, turned out that this prediction while applicable in some small and isolated situations really has not prevailed.

What has prevailed is the continued use of email as a communications tool and a steady encroachment into the collaboration space of these discussion applications. I see a generational gap forming between the emailers and the chatters. Those under the age of about thirty are comfortable messaging each other rather than using their smartphone for its primary purpose - to make phone calls. This tendency towards messaging transferred to the business environment makes email look terribly old fashioned and slow. What the messaging generation (those hooked on iMessage, WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, etc.) expect is to have the clarity of discussion and threading they have in their personal lives, but at work.

So, to be successful in driving new employee engagement, unlocking experiences and improving productivity, all of which fall under the collective banner of "building a better business", we must now also include the group of solutions such as IBM Watson Workspace, Microsoft Teams, Slack and so on.
